questions.question: What is the `currentColor` keyword in CSS?

answer_variants.answer: It represents the current text color of the element.

`currentColor` is a variable that holds the value of the element's `color` property. If not set on the element, it inherits from the parent. It allows you to synchronize background, border, and shadow colors with the text color automatically.
Computed value of the `color` property. It acts as the default value for properties like `border-color`, `box-shadow` (shadow color), and SVG `fill`.
The value of the element's color property.
It's like a chameleon skin function. 'Make the border the same color as the body'.
Dynamic reference to the text color.
Extremely useful for icon sets (SVG) where you want the icon to take the color of the text (e.g., on hover).
It means 'Use the same color as the text'. If the text is red, this border becomes red too.
Since CSS Cascades, `color: blue; border: 1px solid currentColor;` makes a blue border.
A keyword that represents the value of the element's color property.

questions.question: Why can using `em` units for font-size result in unexpectedly large text?

answer_variants.answer: Because `em` multiplies based on the parent's size. If you nest them, they grow exponentialy.

`em` is relative to the *parent's* font size. If you nest lists (`<ul>`) where each list is `1.2em`, the child becomes `1.2 * 1.2 = 1.44em` and the grandchild `1.728em`. This 'compounding' effect is why `rem` (relative to Root) is preferred for layout stability.
Compounding effect due to inheritance. `2em` inside `2em` = `4em`. `rem` avoids this by always referencing `html` root.
Nesting elements with em units causes size compounding.
It's compound interest. 10% on top of 10% on top of 10% gets huge fast.
`em` compounds in nested elements; `rem` does not.
Use `em` for padding/margins if you want them to scale with the component's internal font size, but avoid `em` for font-size itself unless intentional.
If you put a big box inside a big box, CSS multiplies them and makes a Giant box.
`em` on padding is actually relative to the element's *own* font-size, not parent. Nuance!
em is relative to the parent/current font size and compounds in nesting.

questions.question: What is the `ch` unit based on?

answer_variants.answer: The width of the number '0' (zero) character.

The `ch` unit is equal to the advance measure (width) of the glyph '0' (zero) of the element's font. It is highly useful for defining sizing in terms of character count (e.g., a text column that is 60 chars wide for readability).
Advance width of the character '0' in the current font.
Width of the character 0.
It's like measuring a garage by how many cars fit in it.
Width of the '0' glyph.
Often used for `max-width: 60ch` to optimize reading length (typographic best practice).
It's the width of the number zero. Using '10ch' means 'space for 10 zeros'.
In monospace fonts, `1ch` implies exactly 1 character width. In proportional fonts, it's an approximation.
The width of the zero (0) character.

questions.question: How does `isolation: isolate` help with z-index issues?

answer_variants.answer: It creates a new stacking context without needing position or z-index values.

`isolation: isolate` creates a new Stacking Context on the element. This ensures that z-index calculations for its children are contained within it and do not leak out or compete with elements outside. It's cleaner than `transform: translateZ(0)`.
Forces the creation of a Stacking Context. Prevents negative z-index children from rendering behind the parent's background.
Creates a new stacking context.
It creates a sealed glass box. You can stack things inside the box, but nothing pokes out of the box.
Cleanest way to create a stacking context.
Solves the 'dropdown appearing behind other content' bug without starting a z-index war (9999).
It tells the browser 'Treat everything inside me as a separate layer'.
Unlike `opacity: 0.9`, it has no visual side effects.
It defines whether an element must create a new stacking context.

questions.question: What does `minmax(100px, 1fr)` mean in a Grid definition?

answer_variants.answer: The column will be at least 100px, but can grow to fill space.
It defines a size range. The track will be a minimum of `100px` wide. If there is extra space, it will grow to `1fr` (one share of free space). This allows responsive grids that don't crush content.
Function defining a size range >= min and <= max. `min` can be pixels. `max` can be flex `fr` units.
Minimum 100px, maximum 1fr.
Like a balloon. It starts defined size (100px) but expands to fill the container.
At least 100px, but stretchy.
Combined with `repeat(auto-fit, minmax(...))`, this creates fully responsive grids without media queries.
Don't get smaller than 100px. But you can get bigger if there is room.
If the max is less than the min, the max is ignored and min is used.
Defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max.

questions.question: What is the purpose of `object-fit: cover`?

answer_variants.answer: It makes an image fill a box completely, cropping edges if needed, without squishing it.

`object-fit: cover` sizes the image (or video) to maintain its aspect ratio while filling the element's entire content box. The object will be clipped (cropped) to fit. It solves image distortion issues.
Similar to `background-size: cover` but for `` tags. Replaced content is sized to maintain aspect ratio while filling the line box.
Maintains aspect ratio while filling the container (crops overflow).
Like zooming into a photo until it fills the frame. You lose the edges, but the photo looks normal.
Fills container, preserving ratio, cropping edges.
Contrast with `contain`: Contain shows the whole image (letterbox/bars). Cover fills the box (cropping).
It makes the picture fill the square perfectly without looking weird or stretched.
Use `object-position` to control which part of the image remains visible (e.g. `center top`).
Sizes the image to maintain its aspect ratio while filling the element's entire content box.
It styles a parent element when one of its children is focused.

Matches an element if the element itself has focus OR if any of its descendants have focus. This enables 'Parent Styling' based on child stateâ€”e.g., highlighting a whole form row when the input inside it is clicked.
Matches element E if E matches `:focus` or if E has a descendant that matches `:focus`. Bubbles focus state up.
Matches if the element or any descendant has focus.
It's like a motion sensor in a house. If a light turns on in ANY room (child), the whole house (parent) knows.
Parent active when child is focused.
Previously required JavaScript event delegation (`focusin`). Now native CSS.
If you click inside a box, the box itself lights up.
Also works with Shadow DOM focus delegation.
Matches an element if the element itself has focus or if any of its descendants have focus.

questions.question: What is the advantage of using `width: min(100%, 500px)`?

answer_variants.answer: It sets a max width without needing a separate max-width property.
It is a modern, destructive-free shorthand. It means: 'Use 500px, unless the screen is smaller than that, then use 100%'. It replaces the dual declaration of `width: 100%; max-width: 500px;`.
`min()` CSS function. Returns the smallest of the arguments. Context-aware responsiveness.
Sets width to 500px, capped at 100% of parent.
Walk through the small door or the big door, whichever fits.
Responsive cap: 500px max, else 100%.
Reduces LOC (Lines of Code) and prevents horizontal scrollbars automatically.
Be 500px wide. But if the screen is smaller than that, just fill the screen.
See also `clamp()` which takes a min, preferred, and max value.
Sets the width to the smaller of 100% or 500px.

questions.question: Is `pointer-events: none` on a button the same as `disabled` attribute?

answer_variants.answer: No. `pointer-events: none` stops clicks but Keyboard users can still tab to it and activate it.

No. `pointer-events: none` only disables mouse/touch interaction. The button remains in the tab order and can be activated via Enter/Spacebar. The `disabled` HTML attribute removes it from tab order and prevents all forms of activation.
CSS only affects hit-testing of pointer devices. HTML `disabled` is a semantic state that affects focusability, form submission, and accessibility tree.
No. Pointer-events does not disable keyboard interaction.
Pointer-events is hiding the doorbell. Disabled is cutting the wire.
It fails to stop Keyboard activation.
Never rely on CSS for security or logic disabled states.
The CSS one only stops the Mouse. The HTML one stops Everything.
You can add `tabindex='-1'` to fix the keyboard issue, but `disabled` is semantically correct.
pointer-events: none only applies to graphic/pointer interaction, not keyboard interaction.

questions.question: Why do many developers simply apply `* { box-sizing: border-box; }` at the start of every project?

answer_variants.answer: It makes sizing elements much easier and logical.

The default `content-box` adds padding and border *on top* of the specified width, making 100% width elements overflow if they have padding. `border-box` includes padding/border *within* the specified width, making layout math predictable (50% is actually 50%).
It resets the Box Model from the W3C standard (additive) to the IE Quirks mode style (inclusive), which surprisingly turned out to be the more intuitive model for UI layout.
It ensures width includes padding and border.
It prevents the 'Fat Box' problem where packing items (padding) makes the box bigger externally.
Makes width/height calculations intuitive.
This is often colloquially known as the 'International Box Sizing Day' fix (Paul Irish).
It makes sure that if you say a box is 100px wide, it stays 100px wide even if you add a border.
Some prefer `html { box-sizing: border-box; } *, *::before, *::after { box-sizing: inherit; }` to be enabling 3rd party component compatibility.
Applies box-sizing: border-box to all elements to ensure width and height properties include padding and border.
